summary: This document is a news brief/email compilation dated January 22, 2021, covering multiple terrorism-related arrests, global counter-terrorism operations, and domestic extremism incidents in the U.S. It includes reports on an FBI leadership change, a soldier plotting an ISIS attack, arrests related to the January 6 Capitol siege, and international terrorism financing trends. It concludes with a note from a Senior Intelligence Specialist at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the SDNY.

persons.name: David L. Bowdich
persons.context: Announced his retirement from the FBI as the Biden administration took over.

persons.name: Christopher A. Wray
persons.context: Was to be kept on as FBI Director by the Biden administration.

persons.name: Cole James Bridges
persons.context: Arrested for allegedly wanting to help ISIS attack the 9/11 Memorial in NYC and target U.S. soldiers.

persons.name: Samuel Fisher
persons.context: Arrested on the Upper East Side with an SUV loaded with ammunition and tactical gear in connection with the Capitol siege aftermath.

persons.name: Patrick Edward McCaughey III
persons.context: Arrested for using a riot shield against a Capitol police officer during the January 6 siege.

persons.name: Eddy Hartono
persons.role: Director for Enforcement, National Counter Terrorism Agency (BNPT), Indonesia
persons.context: Spoke about continued terrorist recruitment and plotting in Indonesia during the COVID-19 pandemic.

persons.name: Zulkarnaen
persons.context: One of Indonesia's most wanted terrorists, believed behind the 2002 Bali bombings, arrested in December.

persons.name: Upik Lawanga
persons.context: One of Indonesia's most wanted terrorists, suspected of aiding attacks between 2004-2006, arrested in November.

persons.name: Abdullahi Dimbil Ahmed
persons.context: Mastermind of the 2015 Mandera bus attack in Kenya, arrested in Somalia.

persons.name: Alejandro Gertz
persons.context: Considering elevating to international courts a dispute with the U.S. over the dropped investigation of ex-defense minister Salvador Cienfuegos.

persons.name: Salvador Cienfuegos
persons.context: Had U.S. charges dropped and was returned to Mexico; Mexican probe into him was closed.

persons.name: James Cahill
persons.role: President, New York State Building and Construction Trades Council
persons.context: Facing criminal case with allegations of working with the Serbian-American drug-trafficking gang Group America.

persons.name: Alex Saab
persons.context: Faces extradition to the U.S. on money laundering charges.

persons.name: Avril Haines
persons.role: Director of National Intelligence nominee (now confirmed)
persons.context: Pledged to declassify the intelligence report on the murder of Jamal Khashoggi.

persons.name: Jamal Khashoggi
persons.context: Murdered in 2018 in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul; his case is a point of tension in U.S.-Saudi relations.

persons.name: Ron Wyden
persons.context: Questioned Avril Haines during a Senate hearing about declassifying the Khashoggi report.

persons.name: Rita Katz
persons.context: Gave an interview comparing the trajectory of the U.S. Far Right movement to that of ISIS.

persons.name: Ed Markey
persons.context: Expressed concerns about the risks of facial recognition technology.

persons.name: Donald Trump
persons.context: Mentioned in context of the Capitol siege, his pardon of Steve Bannon, and being mocked by the Proud Boys.

persons.name: Joe Biden
persons.context: Mentioned as taking office, keeping FBI Director Wray, and his administration's stance on Saudi Arabia.

persons.name: Steve Bannon
persons.context: Mentioned in an opinion piece criticizing Trump's pardon of him as corrupt and a possible obstruction of justice.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Mentioned in a news item about her hearing being illegally streamed by apparent QAnon followers.

connections.description: Bowdich was the deputy director under FBI Director Wray; Bowdich's retirement coincided with Wray being kept on by the Biden administration.
Bridges communicated online with an FBI undercover agent he believed was with ISIS, leading to his arrest.
Both were arrested in connection with the aftermath of the January 6 Capitol siege, though on separate charges and locations.
As Mexican Attorney General, Gertz was involved in the decision to close the Mexican probe into Cienfuegos and is disputing the U.S. handling of the case.
Senator Wyden questioned Haines during her confirmation hearing about declassifying the Khashoggi report.
Trump pardoned Bannon; the pardon is criticized in an opinion piece as corrupt.

events.title: Arrest of Cole James Bridges
events.description: U.S. soldier Cole James Bridges was arrested for allegedly wanting to help ISIS attack the 9/11 Memorial in NYC and target U.S. soldiers.

events.title: Arrest of Samuel Fisher
events.description: Samuel Fisher was arrested on the Upper East Side with an SUV loaded with ammunition and tactical gear in connection with the Capitol siege aftermath.

events.title: Arrest of Patrick Edward McCaughey III
events.description: Patrick Edward McCaughey III was arrested for using a riot shield against a Capitol police officer during the January 6 siege.

events.title: Capitol Siege
events.description: Rioters stormed the U.S. Capitol, resulting in five deaths, including a police officer, as Congress was certifying electoral votes.

events.title: Biden Inauguration
events.description: Joe Biden was inaugurated as President of the United States.

events.title: U.S. Airstrikes in Somalia
events.description: U.S. Africa Command conducted two airstrikes in Somalia, killing three al-Shabaab operatives and destroying a radio station.

events.title: Arrest of Zulkarnaen
events.description: Indonesian terrorist Zulkarnaen, believed behind the 2002 Bali bombings, was arrested after 19 years.

events.title: Arrest of Upik Lawanga
events.description: Indonesian terrorist Upik Lawanga was arrested after 14 years.

events.title: Arrest of Abdullahi Dimbil Ahmed
events.description: Mastermind of the 2015 Mandera bus attack in Kenya was arrested in Somalia.

events.title: Murder of Jamal Khashoggi
events.description: Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi was murdered in the Saudi consulate in Istanbul.

locations: Upper East Side, New York City (E. 89th St. and York Ave.)
Somalia (Jamaame, Deb Scinnele, Lower Juba region)
keyFacts: FBI Deputy Director David L. Bowdich announced his retirement as the Biden administration took over, while Director Christopher Wray was to be kept on.
U.S. soldier Cole James Bridges was arrested for allegedly plotting with ISIS to attack the 9/11 Memorial in New York City.
Multiple arrests were made in connection with the January 6 Capitol siege, including Samuel Fisher (found with an arsenal in NYC) and Patrick Edward McCaughey III (accused of assaulting an officer).
Indonesian counter-terrorism officials reported continued terrorist recruitment and plotting during the COVID-19 pandemic, with the arrests of long-wanted terrorists Zulkarnaen and Upik Lawanga.

The document highlights global terrorism trends, including the shift to 'funding in place' (localized financing) for terrorist groups, and includes reports on operations against al-Shabaab, ISIS, and other extremist activities worldwide.
